# Scale: Major in G (Mode: Locrian)

## Brief Presentation
The Major scale in G, when used in the Locrian mode, is the seventh mode of the major scale system. In this case, it starts and ends on G and is known as the Locrian mode because it is built on the seventh degree of the major scale. This scale has a unique and dissonant sound due to the flattened 5th scale degree, creating a tense and unresolved feeling.

## Notes and Intervals
- G (1), A (b2), Bb (b3), C (4), D (b5), Eb (b6), F (b7)
- The intervals: Whole step, Half step, Whole step, Whole step, Half step, Whole step, Whole step

## Genre and Musical Flavor
The Locrian mode is rarely used in mainstream music due to its dissonant and unstable sound. It is often found in more experimental and avant-garde styles of music, as it creates tension and can evoke a sense of unease or mystery in a composition. Its unique qualities make it well-suited for creating atmospheric and unconventional music.

## Songs
1. **"Frantic" by Metallica**: This song explores the Locrian mode in the main riff, adding a dark and unsettling flavor to the heavy metal sound.
   
2. **"YYZ" by Rush**: The bassline in this iconic instrumental track by Rush features sections in the Locrian mode, adding complexity and intrigue to the song.
   
3. **"The Dance of Eternity" by Dream Theater**: This progressive metal instrumental showcases various modes, including the Locrian, in its intricate and complex composition.
